In this work, exfoliated carbon nitride (eg-C3N4) was supported with ZnCl2 and NbCl5. The synthesized materials (ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4) were analyzed by XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption, FT-IR, XPS, SEM, TG, CO2-TPD, and NH3-TPD. The eg-C3N4 could disperse well Zn2+ and Nb5+ species via nitrogen-containing groups. The combined Zn2+ and Nb5+ components enhanced the alkaline strength of eg-C3N4 and introduced acidic sites, enabling ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 as solid-base bifunctional catalysts. As heterogeneous catalysts, ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 exhibited superior activity to ZnCl2/eg-C3N4 or NbCl5/eg-C3N4 in the transesterification of EC. At 140 °C of reaction temperature, EC conversion and DMC selectivity reached 80.1% and 100%, respectively. The catalysts showed good recycling performance and were also compared with other recently reported heterogeneous catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) Base catalyst Transesterification Dimethyl carbonate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As the simplest organic carbonate, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) has multiple unique physicochemical properties and versatile reactivity [1]. DMC can be applied as green carbonylation and methylation reagents to substitute traditional hazardous phosgene and dimethyl sulfate, respectively [2]. Also, owing to its good biodegradability, low toxicity, and excellent solubility [3], DMC is extensively used as an electrolyte in Li-based batteries, and a green octane booster for gasoline [1,4]. Conventionally, DMC is produced by phosgenation of methanol, which is now mostly phased out because of its serious corrosiveness to equipment along with severe environmental pollution [5,6]. Oxidative carbonylation of methanol is also a dominant industrial route to produce DMC. However, the catalysts thereof commonly suffered a decline in selectivity to DMC after consecutive recycles [1]. Alternatively, transesterification of ethylene carbonate (EC) or propylene carbonate (PC) with methanol has been proposed as a promising and eco-friendly synthetic route for DMC, as the process can be operated under milder conditions and has no toxic phosgene or CO involved [7]. Meanwhile, ethylene glycol (EG), as the co-product generated in the transesterification route, is also an important bulk chemical. To date, a large number of catalysts have been reported for the transesterification reaction. Homogeneous catalysts represented by sodium methoxide and pyridine are very catalytically active but suffer from disadvantages in catalyst recovery and side reactions including decomposition and polymerization of the products [8,9]. On the other hand, various heterogeneous have been reported for catalytic transesterification in the last five years. Despite the advances, most heterogeneous catalysts generally need to be operated under higher reaction temperatures (>140 °C), less dosage of substrates, and even harsh reaction conditions, which undoubtedly greatly hinders their further practical applications. In view of both basic research and sustainable chemistry, it is highly desired to design a heterogeneous catalyst that can offer high catalytic performance under mild conditions [7,10]. In the last decade, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has emerged as s novel functional material and has been widely applied in many fields [11–17]. In thermal catalysis, owing to its abundant nitrogen-containing functionalities, g-C3N4 is a typical solid base and can promote Knoevenagel condensation [18,19] and transesterification reactions [7,20]. More importantly, such nitrogen-containing groups also enable g-C3N4 to anchor and disperse some metal species including K [21,22], Zn [23], Pd [24], etc. It should be stressed that the catalytic activity of g-C3N4 is largely related to its porosity and specific surface area. The g-C3N4 materials directly synthesized by thermal condensation own very low surface areas and usually show extremely low catalytic activity [20,25]. In addition, in the case of the transesterification of EC with methanol, despite rich nitrogen species, the total basicity strength of g-C3N4 is also limited [21,25]. In this sense, how to utilize this solid base of g-C3N4 and enhance its catalytic activity is still a challenge for catalytic transesterification and even wide base-mediated reactions. Zn- and Nb-containing compounds, including ZnO [26], zinc(II) acetate [27], Nb2O5 [28,29], and the organic complexes [30], are typical acidic catalysts that have been intensively applied in the transesterification and esterification reactions. However, most Zn- and Nb-containing complexes are homogeneous catalysts in these liquid-phase reactions [27,30], while the catalytic activity achieved on unsupported ZnO and Nb2O5 catalysts was limited. Since g-C3N4 has alkaline property and the ability to disperse many metal species, in this work, exfoliated g-C3N4 material was prepared and utilized as a catalyst support for ZnCl2 and NbCl5. The eg-C3N4 could disperse well the Zn2+ and Nb5+ species via nitrogen-containing groups. More importantly, the incorporation of metal species enhanced the alkaline strength of eg-C3N4 and meanwhile introduced acidic sites, enabling ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 as solid-base bifunctional catalysts. As heterogeneous catalysts, ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 exhibited superior catalytic activity to ZnCl2/eg-C3N4 or NbCl5/eg-C3N4 in the transesterification between EC and CH3OH. At 140 °C of reaction temperature and 4 h of reaction time, the conversion of EC and selectivity to DMC were up to 80.1% and 100%, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of g-C3N4 and eg-C3N4 Dicyandiamide (DCDA, 5 g) was put into a ceramic crucible and heated to 550 °C with a heating slope of 3 °C·min−1 and then kept at this temperature for another 4 h. The synthesized yellow solid was g-C3N4. The exfoliated g-C3N4 was prepared through thermal treatment. Namely, g-C3N4 (2 g) was heated at 600 °C for 2 h and the resultant powder was designated as eg-C3N4. 2.1.2 Preparation of ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 ZnCl2 (x = 0–10 mmol) and NbCl5 (y = 0–10 mmol) were dissolved into 20 mL of anhydrous ethanol. eg-C3N4 (1.0 g) was added to the solution and stirred for 1 h. Afterwards, the suspension was heated at 50 °C until the removal of ethanol. The ground powder was transferred into a tubular furnace (N2 atmosphere, 20 mL·min−1), and heated from room temperature to 300–500 °C for 3 h (a heating slope of 2 °C·min−1). The obtained sample was collected and designated as Zn x Nb y Cl/eg-C3N4-T, where x and y indicated the molar amounts (the total of x and y was 10) of ZnCl2 and NbCl5, respectively, and T stood for the heating temperatures. Unless other specified, T was 400 °C. For instance, the Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-500 material meant the material was prepared using 8 mmol of ZnCl2, 2 mmol NbCl5, and 1.0 g of eg-C3N4 and was treated under 500 °C. 2.2 Material characterization The materials were analyzed N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), thermogravimetry (TG), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). The detailed analytic methods and information of instruments are given in the supplementary material. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation Transesterification of EC and CH3OH was conducted in an autoclave (25 mL). CH3OH (250 mmol), EC (25 mmol), and the pre-dried catalyst (0.1 g) were added into the autoclave and mixed well. After being filled with nitrogen gas up to ca. 0.6 MPa, the autoclave was heated at 120 °C for 4 h under stirring. After the completion of the reaction (i.e. 4 h), the autoclave was immersed in ice water to cool down and then exhausted slowly. The reaction mixture was centrifugated and analyzed by GC (SP-6890) equipped with a SE-54 capillary column and FID. Owing to the higher stoichiometric of EC than CH3OH adopted in the reaction, the catalytic conversion was calculated based on EC. The detailed EC conversion and selectivity of DMC (target molecule) were calculated by an area-normalization method, and the calculation equations are as follows: C o n v . = A DMC × f DMC + A HEMC × f HEMC A EC × f EC + A DMC × f DMC + A HEMC × f HEMC S e l . = A DMC × f DMC A DMC × f DMC + A HEMC × f HEMC , where A and f are the peak area and response factor of each component detected by GC. HEMC is the abbreviation of 2-hydroxyethyl methyl carbonate as a byproduct. For the recycling experiment, the reaction mixture was filtrated, and the filtrated catalyst was washed with ethanol (95 wt%, a.q.) three times. After drying under 80 °C for 2 h, the recycled catalyst was used for the next catalytic run without the addition of the fresh catalyst. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Materials characterization Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of g-C3N4, eg-C3N4, and the supported materials. All the samples exhibited type-IV isotherms along with H3 hysteretic loops in the relative pressures (p/p 0) between 0.70 and 0.99. The adsorption quantity in g-C3N4 was very low, suggesting that the materials had almost no accessible porous structure. Similarly, the supported material (Zn8Nb2Cl/g-C3N4-400) has also a very low adsorption quantity. In comparison, eg-C3N4 showed a pronounced hysteresis loop, indicative of mesoporous structure. Apparently, the thermal exfoliation of g-C3N4 effectively enhanced the surface areas. The reason for this variation lies in a certain amount of nitrogen-containing species undergoing decomposition during the thermal treatment, thus generating some interparticle voids [31,32]. The pore size distributions of the samples are presented in Fig. 2. The g-C3N4, eg-C3N4, and supported Zn8Nb2Cl materials had similar average pore sizes (2.9–3.8 nm). Moreover, the pore sizes were evenly distributed. Table 1 lists the specific surface areas and porous properties of the materials. The pristine g-C3N4 sample had a very low surface area (17 m2·g−1) and pore volume (0.06 cm3·g−1). As expected, eg-C3N4 material had a larger specific surface area as well as pore volume than g-C3N4. In addition, the surface areas of Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 materials are related to the heating temperature. Specifically, as the temperature of Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-T was elevated, the surface areas were increased gradually. The introduction of the ZnNbCl component inevitably blocked partial pores of eg-C3N4 support. However, because of heat treatment, some nitrogen-containing species of eg-C3N4 decomposed especially under high temperatures, and therefore the high surface areas were retrieved. The XRD patterns of g-C3N4, eg-C3N4, NbCl5/eg-C3N4, ZnCl2/eg-C3N4, and Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400 are shown in Fig. 3. The XRD pattern of g-C3N4 displayed an insensitive diffraction peak at 2θ = 27.4° (d spacing of 0.33 nm), attributed to the interlayer stacking of graphitic phase, namely (002) faces [33]. In addition, a weak peak appeared at 12.8° (d = 0.69 nm), corresponding to the intralayer stacking of the graphitic phase, i.e. (100) faces [34]. The XRD pattern of eg-C3N4 showed a clear shift of (002) diffraction line towards higher 2θ values, suggesting a lower interlayer spacing in C3N4 than g-C3N4. This is due to the thermal compression of graphitic sheets from g-C3N4 to eg-C3N4, which was also reported previously by Dong et al. [35]. Compared with the eg-C3N4 material, the positions of (002) peaks of the supported materials showed no apparent variation, while the overall intensities of these peaks were weakened. The change could result from the partial collapse of the graphitic stacking structure of eg-C3N4 during the heat treatment with ZnCl2 and NbCl5. Such a phenomenon has also been previously observed in the work involving metal-doped g-C3N4 materials [21,36,37]. Notwithstanding, the graphitic structure of eg-C3N4 remained after the loading of the ZnNbCl component. The XRD patterns of ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 materials adopting different heating temperatures and different Zn/Nb ratios were shown in Fig. S1, and Fig. S2, respectively. Like those of the eg-C3N4 support, the ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 materials revealed diffraction peaks at 2θ = 27.7° and 12.8°. It is worth mentioning that the characteristic diffraction peaks of ZnCl2 and NbCl5 were not detected in Fig. S1, implying that these supported components might be dispersed on the support. The thermal stability of the materials was examined by TG. As illustrated in Fig. S3, the TG curves of both the g-C3N4 and eg-C3N4 materials were stable below 600 °C, without any significant weight loss. Above the temperature, the two TG curves showed drastic declines. As the temperature was ca. 760 °C, there was almost no weight remaining. The weight loss occurring in this range was due to the decomposition of the C–N skeleton of the g-C3N4 framework [38]. Compared with that of eg-C3N4, the weight loss of Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400 occurred at lower temperatures (ca. 450 °C). Similar results were also previously revealed in the work involving metal-doped g-C3N4 materials [39,40], where metal cation interacted with nitrogen atoms of g-C3N4 and meanwhile weakened the thermal stability of the original C–N bonds [11]. That is, in this work, the incorporation of ZnNbCl modified the bonding states of the original eg-C3N4 support, also verifying that ZnNbCl was not merely physically loaded on eg-C3N4. The morphologies of the materials were analyzed by SEM. The SEM image ( Fig. 4) of g-C3N4 revealed agglomerated bulky particles, while eg-C3N4 consisted of a large number of slices, much smaller than g-C3N4 particles. The variation in morphology was due to the exfoliation procedure of g-C3N4, which initiated the partial decomposition of nitrogen-containing groups of g-C3N4. Similar SEM images have also been reported in previous work associated with exfoliated g-C3N4 materials [32,41]. The SEM image of Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400 presented slices like eg-C3N4-400 and there was no clear agglomeration of slices. Fig. 5 is the energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping of Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400, and the corresponding elemental distributions are shown in Fig. S4. The elemental images indicate that C, N, Zn, and Nb elements were quite distributed on the material. FT-IR spectroscopy was used to probe the chemical functionalities of the above materials, as shown in Fig. 6. The spectra of g-C3N4, eg-C3N4, and the supported materials exhibited pronounced transmitting bands in three regions. The intensive peaks of 806 cm−1 corresponded to the in-plane deformation vibration (also called breathing mode) of the heptazine motifs, a characteristic FT-IR signal of g-C3N4 [34]. The multiple bands at 1724–1169 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching vibration of aromatic nitrogen-containing heterocycles. The broad bands from 3356 to 2960 cm−1 were associated with the stretching vibration of amino groups and adsorbed water molecules [42]. In comparison with g-C3N4, eg-C3N4, and its supported materials showed a more intensive band at 3265 cm−1, reflecting these materials owned more nitrogen-containing functionalities. Obviously, this is attributed to the larger surface areas of eg-C3N4 materials. The FT-IR spectra of ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 materials synthesized by different temperatures and Zn/Nb ratios were given in Fig. S5. All the supported materials possessed nearly the same spectra as Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400. XPS was applied to further analyze the surface chemical environment of the above materials. The eg-C3N4 material was dominated by C, N, and O elements ( Fig. 7), and the chemical formula calculated by XPS analysis was C0.79N1O0.041 ( Table 2). The molar ratio of C/N was slightly higher than the value of ideal g-C3N4 (0.75), due to the decomposition of nitrogen-containing fragments in the thermal exfoliation step. The signals of supported metal elements were all detected in the XPS spectra of ZnCl2/eg-C3N4, NbCl5/eg-C3N4, and Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 materials. As listed in Table 2, ZnCl2/eg-C3N4 and NbCl5/eg-C3N4 had higher carbon contents than eg-C3N4. As explained above, the introduction of metal components would induce the subsequent decomposition of nitrogen species of eg-C3N4, in agreement with the finding by TG curves (Fig. S3). As described above, the presence of nitrogen-containing groups is responsible for the solid base of g-C3N4 and its derived materials. In order to figure out the detailed distributions of the nitrogen groups, fine N 1 s spectra were recorded. As displayed in Fig. 8, each spectrum could be deconvoluted into three peaks, corresponding to three types of nitrogen atoms (Scheme S1). For eg-C3N4, the primary peak with a binding energy of 398.3 eV was indexed as sp2 nitrogen atoms (Na) in heptazine units [42], accounting for the main proportion of nitrogen species in g-C3N4. The binding energy of 398.9 eV corresponded to the bridging nitrogen atoms (Nb) linking heptazine rings, and the third peak (centered at 400.6 eV) was attributed to uncondensed amino groups (–NH2 or –NH2, Nc) at the edges of graphitic sheets of g-C3N4 [43]. Like that of the bare eg-C3N4 sample, the N 1 s spectra of supported eg-C3N4 materials can also be resolved into three independent peaks. Table 2 summarizes the distribution of the three nitrogen components. The percentages of Na, Nb, and Nc in eg-C3N4 were 72.1%, 16.3%, and 11.6%, respectively. It is noted that Na atoms are highly conjugated in heptazine units and have rarely alkaline properties [44], while the alkaline strength of Nb is higher than Nc [45]. Therein, the alkaline strength and quantity of g-C3N4 and its derived materials were mainly determined by the fractions of Nb species. As shown in Table 2, the ZnCl2/eg-C3N4 and other supported eg-C3N4 materials had higher distributions of Nb than eg-C3N4. As reported in our previous work [45,46], during the heating treatment procedure, the precursors of metal halide (e.g. ZnCl2 and FeCl3) were able to react with terminal amino groups (Nc), thus generating more Nb species. Therefore, it can be reasonably deduced that the supported eg-C3N4 materials had stronger alkaline than the bare material. Besides N 1 s spectra, we also characterized Zn-containing materials in this work and the high-resolution Zn 2p spectra are shown in Fig. 9. All the spectra revealed two peaks at 1044 and 1021 eV, attributed to 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 orbits of Zn element. The spectrum of pure ZnCl2 was also given. One can see that compared with that of ZnCl2, the peak positions of supported Zn-containing materials underwent a distinct shift to lower binding energies, signifying lower positive charges of Zn cation in these materials. This might be probably owing to the interaction of nitrogen of eg-C3N4 with the supported Zn cation, and such d-p interaction [11,39] is beneficial to the stable dispersion of Zn cation on the surface of eg-C3N4 support. Fig. 10 displays the fine Nb 3d spectra of the Nb-containing materials. The peaks centered at 209.1 and 206.4 eV corresponded to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 orbits of the Nb element. On the other hand, the peak of the 3d5/2 orbit of pure NbCl5 is reported to be located at 208.2 eV [47]. Such shifts toward lower binding energies, like the finding in Zn 2p spectra, also confirmed the interaction between nitrogen species of eg-C3N4 and the supported Nb cation. As evidenced by FT-IR and XPS characterization results, eg-C3N4 and its derived material have rich nitrogen-containing species and therefore are typical solid bases. Regarding this point, CO2-TPD technique was used in order to understand the basicity. The resultant CO2-TPD profiles are depicted in Fig. 11. The eg-C3N4 sample exhibited broad desorption of CO2 ranging from 120 °C to 325 °C, corresponding to weak basic sites on the surface. The ZnCl2/eg-C3N4 material had a very similar peak position (ca. 189 °C) with eg-C3N4. In the case of NbCl5/eg-C3N4, the desorption peak of CO2 was moved towards a higher temperature (230 °C), suggesting the appearance of stronger basic sites in NbCl5/eg-C3N4. Furthermore, compared with the eg-C3N4 materials with single halide, the positions of desorption peak acquired in Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 materials showed further enhancement. According to the analytic results of N 1 s, it can be speculated that such enhancement of alkaline strength from eg-C3N4 to Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 is owing to the increase of Nb species thereof. Since most Zn2+/Nb5+-containing compounds (NbCl5, ZnCl2, Nb2O5, etc.) are typical acid catalysts, NH3-TPD was further employed to survey the acidity. There was no appreciable desorption peak in the TPD curve of eg-C3N4 ( Fig. 12), indicating no acidic sites in this material. NbCl5/eg-C3N4 had a very weak desorption in the range of 200–300 °C, attributed to the presence of a few weak acidic sites, while ZnCl2/eg-C3N4 showed a more intensive desorption signal. As for Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 materials, the desorption peak became much stronger, and the peak positions were ca. 234 °C, corresponding to weak acidic sites. Judging from the CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD profiles, it can be verified that the loading of mixed ZnNbCl component, rather than sole ZnCl2 or NbCl5, effectively enhanced both acidic and basic strength of the eg-C3N4, enabling Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 materials as solid-base solid. 3.2 Catalytic performance First, a blank test without any catalyst was performed in the transesterification reaction of EC and CH3OH. As listed in Table 3, the EC conversion was 23.2%, and the product was solely DMC (entry 1). Upon adding 100 mg of eg-C3N4, the conversion was raised to 30.7%. By comparison, under identical reaction conditions, ZnCl2 showed high catalytic activity in the reaction and the EC conversion was 81.4%. Also, the conversion gained in NbCl5 was higher than the value achieved in eg-C3N4. Despite the high conversion, either ZnCl2 or NbCl5 was completely dissolved in the liquid-phase reaction system, and such a homogeneous catalyst is inconvenient to recycle. On the other hand, the supported ZnCl2 and NbCl5 materials showed inferior catalytic activity to ZnCl2 and NbCl5. In sharp contrast, the incorporation of ZnCl2 and NbCl5 on eg-C3N4 brought out remarkable enhancement in catalytic activity (entries 8–10). However, the use of excessive NbCl5 in ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 resulted in a substantial decline (entry 11); the corresponding EC conversion was almost close to the value obtained in NbCl5/eg-C3N4. Among the various ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 samples, Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 demonstrated the highest activity, affording a DMC yield of 55.9%. In addition, we also tested the Zn8Nb2Cl catalyst supported on g-C3N4. The resultant EC conversion was 40.8% (entry 12), slightly lower than its counterpart, which might be due to the difference in surface areas (Table 1). Table 4 lists the catalytic performances of different Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 materials fabricated with various heating temperatures in transesterification reactions. It is seen that the heating temperature had an obvious impact on the final activity of Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4. The conversion obtained in Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-300 was 59.1%; as the temperature was increased, the EC conversion decreased monotonously. However, it should be pointed out that the catalytic data in Table 4 were only collected in the first catalytic run. Fig. 13 shows the recycling performances of various Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 catalysts within five consecutive catalytic runs. Despite the higher activity of Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-300 in the initial run, the EC conversion of the catalyst showed an apparent decline in the first two running times. After three runs, nearly half the initial conversion dropped. The recycled Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-300 and Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400 catalysts after four runs were then analyzed by XPS (Fig. S6–S10). The high-resolution N 1 s, Zn 2p, and Nb 3d spectra showed no significant difference compared with the profiles of the fresh Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 catalysts. Nevertheless, in the case of Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-300, its content of Zn after several recycling tests declined sharply (Table 2) whereas the Zn content in Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400 showed no clear decrease. On the other hand, as listed in Table 3, ZnCl2 had superior catalytic activity to NbCl5 in this transesterification reaction. According to this analysis, the decrease in activity in recycling experiments can be ascribed to the leaching of the ZnCl2 component. That is, the interaction between Zn and eg-C3N4 support in Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400 would be much steadier than in Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-300, which is responsible for its relatively stable recycling performance. Apart from XPS analysis, the recycled Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400 was also analyzed by XRD (Fig. S1), FT-IR (Fig. S5), and TG (Fig. S3) techniques, and the corresponding results showed that the crystalline structure, main chemical functionalities, and thermal stability had well remained in the recycled catalyst. Since the Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4-400 catalysts showed good stability in the recycling experiment, the impacts of reaction conditions on the catalytic results were also investigated. Fig. 14 describes the conversions and selectivities gained by varying the reaction temperatures. With the increase in the temperature, the EC conversion was increased progressively and the selectivity was still above 99%. As the temperature was adjusted to 140 °C, the DMC yield reached 80%. The influence of reaction time on the catalytic results was also probed. As displayed in Fig. 15 A, the conversion of EC received in the first hour was 28%, and prolonging the reaction, the conversion increased drastically. However, the conversion of EC seemed to level off after five hours of reaction time. Also, the catalytic conversion was sensitive to the feeding dosage of the catalyst (Fig. 15 B). As expected, using more catalyst resulted in a continuous increase in conversion. However, like the finding in the influence of reaction time, as the catalyst mass was higher than 200 mg, no significant increase was observed. As already explained in the introduction, g-C3N4 is a typical solid base and has been widely reported to promote Knoevenagel condensation and transesterification reactions. Wherein, the primary role of g-C3N4 was to activate acidic hydrogen atoms, such as active methylene-containing groups in Knoevenagel condensation and alcoholic hydroxyl groups in transesterification. On the other hand, Zn- and Nb-containing compounds are typical acidic catalysts that have been intensively applied in the transesterification and esterification reactions. The effect of the two cations in the catalytic reaction was mainly to adsorb and activate oxygen atoms in the carbonyl group. Based on some relevant literature [48–51], we proposed a possible mechanism of ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 in this transesterification of EC and CH3OH ( Scheme 1). Initially, CH3OH molecules were adsorbed and dissociated by alkaline nitrogen atoms (i.e. Nb species) of eg-C3N4, then transforming into methoxide anions (CH3O−). Meanwhile, the basic sites of eg-C3N4 turned into conjugated acidic sites (Step 1). On the other hand, oxygen atoms in of C–O bonds of EC molecules were adsorbed by Zn2+ and Nb5+ cations, leading to further polarization of the bonds (Step 2). After that, the methoxide anions attacked the carbon atoms in the C–O bonds of EC, thus generating alkoxide anions (Step 3). Subsequently, another CH3OH molecule and alkoxide anion underwent proton exchange, yielding alkoxide anion and 2-hydroxyethyl methyl carbonate (HEMC, Step 4). The alkoxide anion further reacted with HEMC, generating DMC and ethylene glycol (EG) anion (Step 5). Finally, EG anion reacted with the conjugated acidic sites of eg-C3N4, thus yielding EG (Step 6). Meanwhile, the original basic sites of eg-C3N4 were recovered. Table 5 summarizes the catalytic performance of several heterogeneous catalysts for transesterification of EC and CH3OH reported in the last five years. It should be noted that all the cases were based on batch reactors rather than fixed-bed ones. Most of the reaction temperatures adopted for the catalytic reaction are above 90 °C, and the molar ratios of EC to CH3OH are basically 1:10. Among these catalysts, CaO/carbon and Co-Ca-Zr catalyst demonstrated the highest activity under the lowest reaction temperatures (60–65 °C). Despite this advantage, the major component of these two catalysts is CaO, and the strong base is very easy to adsorb acidic CO2, resulting in subsequent slow inactivation [52]. On the other hand, ionic liquids such as PILs-FL and poly[VRIm-VBA-DVIm] also suffer from complicated procedures in catalyst preparation. Thereby, in viewpoints of both catalyst preparation and performance, the solid-base bifunctional Zn8Nb2Cl/eg-C3N4 in this work might be more suitable for the practical catalytic synthesis of DMC. 4 Conclusion The eg-C3N4 material was synthesized by the thermal exfoliation method, and then a series of ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 materials were prepared by an impregnation approach. The loading of Zn2+ and Nb5+ did not alter the graphitic structure of the eg-C3N4 support. There was an interaction between the supported metal cations and eg-C3N4. Compared with the bare eg-C3N4, the loading of metal species enabled it to have acidic properties, while enhancing the alkaline strength of eg-C3N4. In the transesterification reaction of EC and CH3OH, the ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 composite exhibited superior catalytic activity to ZnCl2/eg-C3N4 and NbCl5/eg-C3N4. At 140 °C of reaction temperature and 4 h of reaction time, the DMC yield could reach 80%. Moreover, the catalyst had good recycling ability. The acid-base bifunctional ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 catalyst is expected to provide a new and clean approach to synthesizing DMC. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic transesterification reaction between ethylene carbonate (EC) with methanol is a sustainable approach for the production of dimethyl carbonate (DMC). In this work, exfoliated carbon nitride (eg-C3N4) was supported with ZnCl2 and NbCl5. The synthesized materials (ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4) were analyzed by XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption, FT-IR, XPS, SEM, TG, CO2-TPD, and NH3-TPD. The eg-C3N4 could disperse well Zn2+ and Nb5+ species via nitrogen-containing groups. The combined Zn2+ and Nb5+ components enhanced the alkaline strength of eg-C3N4 and introduced acidic sites, enabling ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 as solid-base bifunctional catalysts. As heterogeneous catalysts, ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 exhibited superior activity to ZnCl2/eg-C3N4 or NbCl5/eg-C3N4 in the transesterification of EC. At 140 °C of reaction temperature, EC conversion and DMC selectivity reached 80.1% and 100%, respectively. The catalysts showed good recycling performance and were also compared with other recently reported heterogeneous catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Acid–base bifunctional ZnNbCl/eg-C3N4 materials towards catalytic synthesis of dimethyl carbonate via transesterification of ethylene carbonate
